Journal.Title: The Science of the total environment

Article.ArticleTitle: Observations and modeling of OH and HO<sub>2</sub> radicals in Chengdu, China in summer 2019.

AbstractText: This study reports on the first continuous measurements of ambient OH and HO<sub>2</sub> radicals at a suburban site in Chengdu, Southwest China, which were collected during 2019 as part of a comprehensive field campaign 'CompreHensive field experiment to explOre the photochemical Ozone formation mechaniSm in summEr - 2019 (CHOOSE-2019)'. The mean concentrations (11:00-15:00) of the observed OH and HO<sub>2</sub> radicals were 9.5 × 10<sup>6</sup> and 9.0 × 10<sup>8</sup> cm<sup>-3</sup>, respectively. To investigate the state-of-the-art chemical mechanism of radical, closure experiments were conducted with a box model, in which the RACM2 mechanism updated with the latest isoprene chemistry (RACM2-LIM1) was used. In the base run, OH radicals were underestimated by the model for the low-NO regime, which was likely due to the missing OH recycling. However, good agreement between the observed and modeled OH concentrations was achieved when an additional species X (equivalent to 0.25 ppb of NO mixing ratio) from one new OH regeneration cycle (RO<sub>2</sub> + X → HO<sub>2</sub>, HO<sub>2</sub> + X → OH) was added into the model. Additionally, in the base run, the model could reproduce the observed HO<sub>2</sub> concentrations. Discrepancies in the observed and modeled HO<sub>2</sub> concentrations were found in the sensitivity runs with HO<sub>2</sub> heterogeneous uptake, indicating that the impact of the uptake may be less significant in Chengdu because of the relatively low aerosol concentrations. The ROx (= OH + HO<sub>2</sub> + RO<sub>2</sub>) primary source was dominated by photolysis reactions, in which HONO, O<sub>3</sub>, and HCHO photolysis accounted for 34%, 19%, and 23% during the daytime, respectively. The efficiency of radical cycling was quantified by the radical chain length, which was determined by the NO to NO<sub>2</sub> ratio successfully. The parameterization of the radical chain length may be very useful for the further determinations of radical recycling.
